column2: My uncle made no doubt about it at all; I both desired and feared.
column3: My uncle made no doubt about it at all; I both desired and feared.

column2: After spending an hour in the contemplation of this marvellous spectacle, we returned to the shore to regain the grotto, and I fell asleep in the midst of the strangest thoughts.
column3: After spending an hour in the contemplation of this marvellous spectacle, we returned to the shore to regain the grotto, and I fell asleep in the midst of the strangest thoughts.

column2: CHAPTER XXXI.
column3: CHAPTER thirty one.

column2: PREPARATIONS FOR A VOYAGE OF DISCOVERY
column3: PREPARATIONS FOR A VOYAGE OF DISCOVERY

column2: The next morning I awoke feeling perfectly well.
column3: The next morning I awoke feeling perfectly well.

column2: I thought a bathe would do me good, and I went to plunge for a few minutes into the waters of this mediterranean sea, for assuredly it better deserved this name than any other sea.
column3: I thought a bathe would do me good, and I went to plunge for a few minutes into the waters of this mediterranean sea, for assuredly it better deserved this name than any other sea.

column2: I came back to breakfast with a good appetite.
column3: I came back to breakfast with a good appetite.

column2: Hans was a good caterer for our little household; he had water and fire at his disposal, so that he was able to vary our bill of fare now and then. For dessert he gave us a few cups of coffee, and never was coffee so delicious.
column3: Hans was a good caterer for our little household; he had water and fire at his disposal, so that he was able to vary our bill of fare now and then. For dessert he gave us a few cups of coffee, and never was coffee so delicious.

column2: Now, said my uncle, "now is the time for high tide, and we must not lose the opportunity to study this phenomenon."
column3: Now, said my uncle, "now is the time for high tide, and we must not lose the opportunity to study this phenomenon."

column2: What! the tide! I cried.
column3: What! the tide! I cried.

column2: Can the influence of the sun and moon be felt down here?
column3: Can the influence of the sun and moon be felt down here?

column2: Are not all bodies subject throughout their mass to the power of universal attraction?
column3: Are not all bodies subject throughout their mass to the power of universal attraction?

column2: This mass of water cannot escape the general law.
column3: This mass of water cannot escape the general law.

column2: And in spite of the heavy atmospheric pressure on the surface, you will see it rise like the Atlantic itself."

column2: Here is the tide rising, I cried.

column2: Yes, Axel; and judging by these ridges of foam, you may observe that the sea will rise about twelve feet.
column3: Yes, Axel; and judging by these ridges of foam, you may observe that the sea will rise about twelve feet.

column2: This is wonderful, I said.
column3: This is wonderful, I said.

column2: No; it is quite natural.
column3: No; it is quite natural.

column2: You may say so, uncle; but to me it is most extraordinary, and I can hardly believe my eyes.	You may say so, uncle; but to me it is most extraordinary, and I can hardly believe my eyes.

column2: Who would ever have imagined, under this terrestrial crust, an ocean with ebbing and flowing tides, with winds and storms?"
column3: Who would ever have imagined, under this terrestrial crust, an ocean with ebbing and flowing tides, with winds and storms?"

column2: Well, replied my uncle, "is there any scientific reason against it?"
column3: Well, replied my uncle, "is there any scientific reason against it?"

column2: No; I see none, as soon as the theory of central heat is given up. "So then, thus far," he answered, "the theory of Sir Humphry Davy is confirmed."

column2: Evidently it is; and now there is no reason why there should not be seas and continents in the interior of the earth.
column3: Evidently it is; and now there is no reason why there should not be seas and continents in the interior of the earth.

column2: No doubt, said my uncle; "and inhabited too."
column3: No doubt, said my uncle; "and inhabited too."

column2: To be sure, said I; "and why should not these waters yield to us fishes of unknown species?"
column3: To be sure, said I; "and why should not these waters yield to us fishes of unknown species?"

column2: At any rate, he replied, "we have not seen any yet."
column3: At any rate, he replied, "we have not seen any yet."

column2: Well, let us make some lines, and see if the bait will draw here as it does in sublunary regions.
column3: Well, let us make some lines, and see if the bait will draw here as it does in sublunary regions.

column2: We will try, Axel, for we must penetrate all secrets of these newly discovered regions.
column3: We will try, Axel, for we must penetrate all secrets of these newly discovered regions.

column2: But where are we, uncle? for I have not yet asked you that question, and your instruments must be able to furnish the answer.

column2: Horizontally, three hundred and fifty leagues from Iceland.
column3: Horizontally, three hundred and fifty leagues from Iceland.

column2: So much as that?

column2: I am sure of not being a mile out of my reckoning.

column2: And does the compass still show south-east?

column2: As for its dip, a curious fact is coming to light, which I have observed carefully: that the needle, instead of dipping towards the pole as in the northern hemisphere, on the contrary, rises from it."
column3: As for its dip, a curious fact is coming to light, which I have observed carefully: that the needle, instead of dipping towards the pole as in the northern hemisphere, on the contrary, rises from it."

column2: Would you then conclude, I said, "that the magnetic pole is somewhere between the surface of the globe and the point where we are?"
column3: Would you then conclude, I said, "that the magnetic pole is somewhere between the surface of the globe and the point where we are?"

column2: Exactly so; and it is likely enough that if we were to reach the spot beneath the polar regions, about that seventy-first degree where Sir James Ross has discovered the magnetic pole to be situated, we should see the needle point straight up.	Exactly so; and it is likely enough that if we were to reach the spot beneath the polar regions, about that seventy first degree where Sir james Ross has discovered the magnetic pole to be situated, we should see the needle point straight up.

column2: Therefore that mysterious centre of attraction is at no great depth."
column3: Therefore that mysterious centre of attraction is at no great depth."

column2: I remarked: "It is so; and here is a fact which science has scarcely suspected."
column3: I remarked: "It is so; and here is a fact which science has scarcely suspected."

column2: Science, my lad, has been built upon many errors; but they are errors which it was good to fall into, for they led to the truth.

column2: What depth have we now reached?
column3: What depth have we now reached?

column2: We are thirty-five leagues below the surface.

column2: So, I said, examining the map, "the Highlands of Scotland are over our heads, and the Grampians are raising their rugged summits above us."
column3: So, I said, examining the map, "the Highlands of Scotland are over our heads, and the Grampians are raising their rugged summits above us."

column2: Yes, answered the Professor laughing.

column2: The great Architect has built it of the best materials; and never could man have given it so wide a stretch.
column3: The great Architect has built it of the best materials; and never could man have given it so wide a stretch.

column2: What are the finest arches of bridges and the arcades of cathedrals, compared with this far reaching vault, with a radius of three leagues, beneath which a wide and tempest-tossed ocean may flow at its ease?"
column3: What are the finest arches of bridges and the arcades of cathedrals, compared with this far reaching vault, with a radius of three leagues, beneath which a wide and tempest tossed ocean may flow at its ease?"

column2: We will continue our journey, everything having gone on well so far."

column2: But I should like to see my boat first."
column3: But I should like to see my boat first."

column2: Come, and you will see for yourself."

column2: After half an hour's walking, on the other side of the promontory which formed the little natural harbour, I perceived Hans at work.

column2: In a few more steps I was at his side.

column3: To my great surprise a half finished raft was already lying on the sand, made of a peculiar kind of wood, and a great number of planks, straight and bent, and of frames, were covering the ground, enough almost for a little fleet.

column3: Uncle, what wood is this? I cried.
